subject: Julie Chen: A Night of Gala Celebrations
body:
CBSNews.com












  Home | U.S. | World | Politics | SciTech | Health | Entertainment | Business | Opinion | Sports | Blogs | Interactives | Video 

  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday Morning | Face The Nation 



       May 7, 
      2007


Hi, 
      everybody,

The town of Greensburg, 
      Kansas, devastated by a 
      category F-5 tornado, is 95 percent 
      gone. Its residents are in our 
      thoughts and prayers today 
      as they try to put their homes and lives back 
      together. 
Meanwhile, Washington
is abuzz with the White 
      House state dinner tonight in honor of the Queen and her husband, Prince 
      Phillip.  It is certainly a big 
      night for fashion both there and here in New York City.  While the men in DC 
      will be donning their white ties and tails and the ladies will be 
      decked out in their finest gowns to meet the Queen, we here in New York will be honoring 
      some royalty from the fashion world. The Metropolitan Museum of Art's 
      Costume Institute is holding its annual gala, which will 
      be hosted by Vogue's editor-in-chief, Anna Wintour. This is THE 
      fashion of event of the year and the parade of couture gowns and 
      jewels makes Oscar night look pedestrian by comparison. This 
      year the Institute is celebrating the work of French 
      designer Paul Poiret, whose ground-breaking designs 100 years 
      ago freed women from their corsets and borrowed a page from the 
      Far East in his introduction of 
      "Orientalism."
 
It was 
      fascinating to hear author David Talbot talk about Jack 
      and Bobby Kennedy this morning. Despite 
      all that has been written about them, we never tire of hearing more 
      stories about this family -- or even repeats of ones 
      we're already familiar with.  The Kennedys are the closest thing 
      this country has had to a "royal family" and we are fortunate to have 
      surviving members of the family continue their good works.  
      
 
Also, it was exciting to talk to the three final teams 
      of the Amazing Race today as Phil Keogan presented the winners, Eric and 
      Danielle, with their $1 million 
      check.  It was also nice to 
      see Team Guido, Ian and Terri and Team Kentucky turn out 
      to support them.  It was like a mini-reunion.  
      Congratulations to Eric and Danielle, and the rest of the 
      finalists, on a job well done.  I can't wait for the next 
      season, but in the meantime, Phil told us he's doing a summer series for The Early 
      Show called "Keogan's Heroes" where he'll travel the world in search of 
      people who are doing amazing 
      things.  
 
Tomorrow, Lou Dobbs will be on 
      hand to give his weekly commentary; "CSI" Week continues with an interview with 
      David Caruso of "CSI: Miami"; we'll find out which diet plans Consumer 
      Reports magazine says can really do the trick; and Dennis Haysbert of the 
      CBS series "The Unit" will drop 
      by for a visit.
Take care,
 

Julie ChenEarlyShow@cbs.com
